Award.AwardTitle: Photochromic Compounds and Materials: Photodiffraction, Dynamics, and Photomechanical Effects
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jeffrey Rack of the Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology at Ohio University will develop new classes of photochromic transition metal complexes. Photochromic complexes are those that change their color when exposed to light. The goal of this research is to create new examples of these complexes, to study their properties, and to discover new photoactive materials comprised of the photochromic compounds. The project lies at the interface of inorganic, physical, and materials chemistry, and is well suited to the education of scientists at all levels. Particular efforts will be made to train students from groups traditionally underrepresented in science.

The overall goals of this project are to increase the number and types of photochromic transition metal complexes, to discover new photoactive materials, and to study how these photochromic transformations occur. Photochromic transition metal complexes efficiently and rapidly convert photonic energy to potential energy to trigger excited state electronic and molecular structural rearrangements. The mode of action is an excited state linkage isomerism of a bonded chelating sulfoxide from S to O and O to S. This project will examine these systems across three specific aims: 1) synthesis of new photochromic Cu sulfoxide complexes, 2) creation of new photorefractive materials comprising ruthenium sulfoxide complexes, 3) investigation of existing and new complexes by ultrafast pump-probe spectroscopy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photochromic compounds and materials are those that change color when exposed to light. These materials have broad applications ranging from molecular information storage to high technology optical components to novelty items, such as t-shrits and frisbees. We continued our development of a unique class of photochromic materials. In these materials, light prompts a molecular rearrangement of a portion of the molecule. A unique feature of the compounds is the broad color response that they exhibit upon irradiation. These compounds can proceed from colorless to a deep red. Most organic chromophores do not show such a broad color response. Most of efforts in the past granting period have been to investigate the speed of the photochromic reaction and the efficiency of the photochromic reaction. We have used femtosecond to nanosecond laser spectroscopic techniques to learn how these molecules use light energy to facilitate molecular rearrangement. 

Funds from this project provided salary for undergraduate and graduate students as well as summer salary for the PI. In addition, funds from this project permitted purchase of supplies and chemicals in order to meet the goals of the project. Funds from this project allowed student travel to conferences, which let them meet and discuss their results with other scientists. Scientific discussion is an important part of training. Students associated with this project learn cutting-edge tools in synthesis and spectroscopy, and are gain experience in modern chemical theories that bridge the traditional chemical sub-disciplines of inorganic chemistry, physical chemistry, organic chemistry, analytical chemistry and materials science.
